txt.en: 'I will put the bait on that flat stone, [placeholder]. Ready yourself!'

'I have the crawler-remains you gathered, [placeholder]; do you smell their awful stench? To the hill-beasts, this odour will be impossible to resist!\n\n'Let us begin our hunt, and we will lure Bangrath and Murragrath from hiding. Keep a watchful eye, for hill-beasts will be drawn to the scent of the bait I carry.'
'Murragrath is defeated! We are victorious, [placeholder], despite the interference of Drostan.'
'This will call Bangrath and Murragrath, I am sure of it.'
Instance: The Matron and the Master
'To me, [placeholder]! Bangrath is here!'
Tasgall has been defeated
Instance: The Matron and the Master
Tasgall's hunt has brought the two of you to the slopes of Nád Nathair.
'Drostan, we have to go! Something comes!'
Talk to Tasgall
Escort Tasgall to the hill-beast nest in Nád Nathair
'I thought I smelled the odour of the Trév Gállorg here.'
'And you thought it was just the smell of hill-beast.'
'Strong words from a coward such as you, Tasgall.'
'You have not called for Clúcath against us. You tremble at the memory of our strength.'
'I hope this [placeholder] can fight, Tasgall. You are on your own!'
Tasgall's plan is ready, and the two of you must attempt to end the threat of Bangrath and Murragrath.
'Let us go, [placeholder]. Do not let the rain interfere with your concentration!'
'We are seen, [placeholder]. Steel yourself!'
'Thus ends Bangrath; she will no longer cause us pain. But where is Murragrath?'
'There are more hill-beasts approaching.'
'Hold, [placeholder]! I hear footsteps approaching!'
'We make our stand here, by this tree!'
'Behind us, [placeholder]!'
'Stay alert. The Trév Duvárdain are not to be trusted.'
'We are safe for now, but must press on.'

'We have done very well this day, [placeholder], despite the interference of the Trév Duvárdain. Tell me if you are ready to return to my camp-site; I will not speak of Drostan and his ilk until we are safely out of danger.'
'You are not worthy of notice, Drostan. I would not sully my blade with your blood.'
